Question.Subject: what does it mean when i get a dns timeout error?
Question.Content:
ok guys this is starting to get really frustrating... im at school and usually i can log onto my college's internet but since last week i cant anymore. every time i go onto the internet via firefox or internet explorer it says connection is successful but i have a dns timeout error... and its starting to get really irritating not being able to use the internet at school especially on my own laptop
any help is appreciated thanks,
-karl t.
Question.ChosenAnswer:
Basically the error message is exactly right; your computer cannot reach the DNS server for some reason. The DNS server is the Domain Name Server, it is in charge of converting your website names into IP addresses; such as google.com is actually 72.14.204.103 (it has multiple addresses).
## Troubleshooting Steps ## Go to Start > Control Panel > Network Connections > right click on your "Connected" device > select Repair or Fix or Renew Try to surf, if it fails, continue.
Bring up a CMD prompt. Go to Start > Run > type "cmd" > hit "enter", ok, or run. Next type "ipconfig /all" and look for "dns servers" If it's blank then you need to fill it in, if it has IPs then they could be wrong. Type "ipconfig /release" Type "ipconfig /renew" If it's successful, try to get on the internet, if not continue.
Get the DNS server ip address from either a working computer or from your network administrator. Once you get the IP address go to Start > Control Panel > Network Connections > right click on your "Connected" device > Properties > double click TCP/IP Settings (v4) > then select "Use the following DNS servers" > put in the addresses and hit Finish / ok. Try to get on the internet again; if unsuccessful, continue.
Type "nslookup www.google.com" If it *doesn't* come up with an address, it's not something you can fix. If it does, continue. Type "ping <ip address>" If it's successful then put that address in your web browser, if it works then it's a problem with the DNS server and it's outside your permissions to fix.

Type "ping <ip address>" If it's successful then put that address in your web browser, if it works then it's a problem with the DNS server and it's outside your permissions to fix.
